Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Supplemental Fluid Administration on Postoperative Wound Infections in Elective Colon Resections

Trial_Design.evidence: randomly assigned to small volume (8 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=124) or large volume (16-18 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=129) fluid management

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to small volume (8 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=124) or large volume (16-18 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=129) fluid management

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether supplemental fluid administration during and after elective colon resections decreases the incidence of postoperative wound infections.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of surgical wound infections, defined by purulent exudate with culture-positive pathogenic bacteria or CDC criteria, assessed by a blinded observer within 15 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using [randomisation method], with allocation concealment ensured by [method].

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomly assigned to small volume (8 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=124) or large volume (16-18 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=129) fluid management

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the small fluid group, 14 patients developed surgical wound infections, compared to 11 in the large fluid group (P=0.46).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.
